titlStmt.titl: Alberta Benchmark Survey 2008: What Adults Know About Child Development

citation.biblCit: Rikhy, Shivani; Tough, Suzanne; Trute, Barry; Benzies, Karen; Davey, Heather; Johnston, David W., 2016, "Alberta Benchmark Survey 2008: What Adults Know About Child Development", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10810, UAL Dataverse, V4

titlStmt.titl: Alberta Benchmark Survey 2008: What Adults Know About Child Development

stdyInfo.abstract:
The Alberta Benchmark Survey (2008) is a computer-assisted telephone survey that aimed to learn what adults and parents in Alberta knew about children's developmental milestones and strategies to support optimal child development. As well, the survey aimed to obtain information about Albertans' beliefs about child care and children's issues, where parents obtained information about child development, and what parenting strategies they used. Individuals living in Alberta and over the age of 18 were eligible if they had contact with a child under the age of 14 within 6 months and had a phone that could be accessed by random direct dialing.

These metadata are also available through SAGE's searchable metadata website:
http://sagemetadata.policywise.com/nada/index.php/catalog/5

sumDscr.geogCover: Calgary Health Region, Alberta; Capital Health Region, Alberta; Rural Health Regions, Alberta
sumDscr.universe: Albertans who are 18 years or older, who can be reached by a landline, and who had interaction with a child under the age of 14 years in the past 6 months

dataColl.sampProc: Gender quotas were maintained (3:1 female to male) because women are more likely to be primary caregivers of young children. 1/3 participants from Calgary Health Region; 1/3 participants from Capital Health Region; 1/3 participants from Rural Health Regions
dataColl.deviat: The "United Way of Calgary" and "Success by Six" sought an additional sample of at least 400 respondents from the city of Calgary and Edmonton. Quotas were thus enhances in both cities.
dataColl.collSitu: The main study questionnaire took 25 minutes to complete (excluding introductory and screening questions). Respondents who currently were a parent or guardian of a child under 14 years answered additional sections and therefore, had a longer average interview length, at 30 minutes. Non-parents/guardians had an average interview length of 20 minutes.

dataAccs.notes:
We are accepting proposals for our 2018 Secondary Data Use Grant starting February 20, 2018. This grant provides $5,000 to successful applicants to undertake research using data in SAGE. The term of the grant is 12 months. The grant offers an excellent opportunity for trainees and new researchers to work with existing birth cohort and survey data. Deadline for applications is April 27, 2018 at 4:00 PM MST.

https://policywise.com/initiatives/sage/secondary-data-use-grant/

No special access conditions or procedures beyond the standard SAGE data access protocol. See: https://policywise.com/initiatives/sage/accessing-data/

setAvail.avlStatus: Level 2 security (access through the SAGE Virtual Research Environment)

useStmt.specPerm: No vetting conditions beyond the standard SAGE vetting requirements checklist
useStmt.citReq: Data must be cited in any publication or report using study bibliographic citation; Data producer(s) must receive co-authorship on any publication or report where scientifically appropriate
useStmt.conditions: No special access conditions or procedures beyond the standard SAGE data access protocol

otherMat.txt: Contains the final report about the results of the 2008 Benchmark Survey: What Adults Know About Child Development. Outlines major findings from the survey
